pullrequest.title: Quick fix for config errors after qtutils 2 changes

content.raw:
I was going to say that this only temporarily fixes the problem since Qt objects would still be stored, and so future updates will break again. But as you mention in the corresponding bug report, since we are now using API v2 everywhere, Qt objects will no longer be stored. We could ensure this is true everywhere by using `ast.literal_eval()` instead of `eval()`, but that is a topic for another time.

So I see this fix as appropriate backward compatibility.
content.html:
I was going to say that this only temporarily fixes the problem since Qt objects would still be stored, and so future updates will break again. But as you mention in the corresponding bug report, since we are now using API v2 everywhere, Qt objects will no longer be stored. We could ensure this is true everywhere by using ast.literal_eval() instead of eval(), but that is a topic for another time.

So I see this fix as appropriate backward compatibility.

pullrequest.title: Quick fix for config errors after qtutils 2 changes

content.raw: By the way, one time phil was asking why he was not added as a reviewer when the default reviewers are him and me. This is a bug in bitbucket - default reviewers are based on the source fork, not on the destination, and when @PhyNerd forked this repo, it must have been before we set default reviewers. Silly, but explains why the reviewers aren't always what we expect.
content.html: By the way, one time phil was asking why he was not added as a reviewer when the default reviewers are him and me. Silly, but explains why the reviewers aren't always what we expect.

pullrequest.title: Quick fix for config errors after qtutils 2 changes

content.raw:
By the way, if you're actually running with Qt5 in the lab (which it seem you probably are, if this bug bit you?), you're probably likely to hit problems with the drag-drop tabs in BLACS, which seem to be not very happy in Qt5. Perhaps you could test the new dragdroptabs? My fork is a mess so if you pull from be sure to do `hg pull --branch dragdroptab #!/cbillington/labscript_utils` to just get the relevant branch.

Edit: once I resolve the merge conflicts.

pullrequest.title: Quick fix for config errors after qtutils 2 changes

content.raw:
No PyQt5 till now I'm planing to switch next week. 

I just deployed the qtutils2 stuff and abstraction layer today and let's just say the guys in the lab were not happy for 15 minutes... But this special case didn't come up in testing so what can you do? 

The problem occurs under qututils 2 with PyQt4 because the eval is something like "PyQt4.QString" and since there is no PyQt4 in the namespace things break. 

Your drag'n drop tabs are running in our lab for a week now no problems there till now. (I think I mentioned this somewhere)
content.html:
No PyQt5 till now I'm planing to switch next week.

I just deployed the qtutils2 stuff and abstraction layer today and let's just say the guys in the lab were not happy for 15 minutes... But this special case didn't come up in testing so what can you do?

The problem occurs under qututils 2 with PyQt4 because the eval is something like "PyQt4.QString" and since there is no PyQt4 in the namespace things break.

Your drag'n drop tabs are running in our lab for a week now no problems there till now. (I think I mentioned this somewhere)

pullrequest.title: Quick fix for config errors after qtutils 2 changes

content.raw:
Interesting - yeah repr() and eval() is not the best for that sort of thing. At least if it were pickling it would have imported Qt4 itself upon unpickling rather than relying on it being in the namespace. That's not a great idea either though - hence ast.literal_eval to ensure you're only using Python built-in types.


Edit: And good to hear about the dragdroptabs - I'll comment on its pull request to see if people are happy to merge it based on this.
content.html:
Interesting - yeah repr() and eval() is not the best for that sort of thing. At least if it were pickling it would have imported Qt4 itself upon unpickling rather than relying on it being in the namespace. That's not a great idea either though - hence ast.literal_eval to ensure you're only using Python built-in types.

Edit: And good to hear about the dragdroptabs - I'll comment on its pull request to see if people are happy to merge it based on this.
